QakBot can use signed loaders to evade detection.
FIN7 has signed Carbanak payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates.
Silence has used a valid certificate to sign their primary loader Silence.Downloader .
Patchwork has signed malware with self-signed certificates from fictitious and spoofed legitimate software companies.
Adversaries may create self-signed code signing certificates that can be used during targeting.
Prior to Code Signing, adversaries may purchase or steal code signing certificates for use in operations.
Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a program from a developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with.
Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries.
Matryoshka is capable of providing Meterpreter shell access.
Bandook can support commands to execute Java-based payloads.
FELIXROOT opens a remote shell to execute commands on the infected system.
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D can run commands through a terminal on the victim’s machine.
MoonWind can execute commands via an interactive command shell.
APT32 has used COM scriptlets to download Cobalt Strike beacons.
Fox Kitten has used a Perl reverse shell to communicate with C2.
Windigo has used a Perl script for information gathering.
APT28 uses cmd.exe to execute commands and custom backdoors.
BRONZE BUTLER uses the command-line interface.
Cobalt Group has used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of launching cmd.exe to execute shell commands.
Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines, using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.
Source code payloads may also be encrypted, encoded, and/or embedded within other files, such as those delivered as a Phishing.
Rocke has compiled malware, delivered to victims as .c files, with the GNU Compiler Collection .
Adversaries may abuse Compiled HTML files  to conceal malicious code.
CHM content is displayed using underlying components of the Internet Explorer browser  loaded by the HTML Help executable program .
A custom CHM file containing embedded payloads could be delivered to a victim then triggered by User Execution.

Some adversaries may employ sophisticated means to compromise computer components and install malicious firmware that will execute adversary code outside of the operating system and main system firmware or BIOS.

COM is an inter-process communication  component of the native Windows application programming interface  that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces.
Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically binary Dynamic Link Libraries  or executables .
TrickBot used COM to setup scheduled task for persistence.
MuddyWater has used malware that has the capability to execute malicious code via COM, DCOM, and Outlook.
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by hijacked references to Component Object Model  objects.
Some variants of ADVSTORESHELL achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.
KONNI has modified ComSysApp service to load the malicious DLL payload.
APT28 has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate MMDeviceEnumerator object with a payload.
Utilizing an existing persona may engender a level of trust in a potential victim if they have a relationship, or knowledge of, the compromised persona.
Kessel has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.
ThiefQuest searches through the /Users/ folder looking for executable files.
When the file is executed, the ThiefQuest code is executed first.
Adversaries may manipulate software dependencies and development tools prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.
Popular open source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.
APT41 gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.
Dragonfly has placed trojanized installers on legitimate vendor app stores.
A container administration service such as the Docker daemon, the Kubernetes API server, or the kubelet may allow remote management of containers within an environment.

In Kubernetes, if an adversary has sufficient permissions, they may gain remote execution in a container in the cluster via interaction with the Kubernetes API server, the kubelet, or by running a command such as kubectl exec.
Adversaries may attempt to discover containers and other resources that are available within a containers environment.
For ease of use, Control Panel items typically include graphical menus available to users after being registered and loaded into the Control Panel.
Control Panel items can be executed directly from the command line, programmatically via an application programming interface  call, or by simply double-clicking the file.
In cloud environments, adversaries may create accounts that only have access to specific services, which can reduce the chance of detection.
Sandworm Team added a login to a SQL Server with sp_addlinkedsrvlogin.
Creating a new instance may allow an adversary to bypass firewall rules and permissions that exist on instances currently residing within an account.
Processes can be created with the token and resulting security context of another user using features such as CreateProcessWithTokenW and runas.

Creating processes with a different token may require the credentials of the target user, specific privileges to impersonate that user, or access to the token to be used  or Make and Impersonate Token.
Turla RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.
Adversaries may install new services, daemons, or agents that can be configured to execute at startup or a repeatable interval in order to establish persistence.
Malicious hooking mechanisms may capture API calls that include parameters that reveal user authentication credentials.
* **Import address table  hooking**, which use modifications to a process’s IAT, where pointers to imported API functions are stored.
* **Inline hooking**, which overwrites the first bytes in an API function to redirect code flow.
NOKKI uses the Windows call SetWindowsHookEx and begins injecting it into every GUI process running on the victim's machine.
Zeus Panda hooks processes by leveraging its own IAT hooked functions.
PLATINUM is capable of using Windows hook interfaces for information gathering such as credential access.
Occasionally, large numbers of username and password pairs are dumped online when a website or service is compromised and the user account credentials accessed.
Typically, management services over commonly used ports are used when stuffing credentials.

Commonly targeted services include the following:
* SSH 
* Telnet 
* FTP 
* NetBIOS / SMB / Samba 
* LDAP 
* Kerberos 
* RDP / Terminal Services 
* HTTP/HTTP Management Services 
* MSSQL 
* Oracle 
* MySQL 
* VNC 
In addition to management services, adversaries may "target single sign-on  and cloud-based applications utilizing federated authentication protocols," as well as externally facing email applications, such as Office 365.
Chimera has used credential stuffing against victim's remote services to obtain valid accounts.
Leviathan has collected compromised credentials to use for targeting efforts.
TrickBot can obtain passwords stored in files from several applications such as Outlook, Filezilla, OpenSSH, OpenVPN and WinSCP.
BlackEnergy has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat!
Smoke Loader searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.
This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.
Pysa has extracted credentials from the password database before encrypting the files.
Hildegard has searched for SSH keys, Docker credentials, and Kubernetes service tokens.
MuddyWater has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.
Fox Kitten has accessed files to gain valid credentials.
A module in Prikormka collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.
Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store; however, methods exist to extract plaintext credentials from web browsers.

The plaintext password can then be obtained by passing the encrypted credentials to the Windows API function CryptUnprotectData, which uses the victim’s cached logon credentials as the decryption key.
OLDBAIT collects credentials from Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, and Eudora.
Olympic Destroyer contains a module that tries to obtain stored credentials from web browsers.
BlackEnergy has used a plug-in to gather credentials from web browsers including FireFox, Google Chrome, and Internet Explorer.
Lokibot has demonstrated the ability to steal credentials from multiple applications and data sources including Safari and the Chromium and Mozilla Firefox-based web browsers.
Trojan.Karagany can steal data and credentials from browsers.
Chaes can steal login credentials and stored financial information from the browser.
QakBot has collected usernames and passwords from Firefox and Chrome.
APT37 has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.
Stolen Pencil has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from web browsers.
TA505 has used malware to gather credentials from Internet Explorer.
APT3 has used tools to dump passwords from browsers.
ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to steal credentials from installed web browsers including Microsoft Internet Explorer and Google Chrome.
The cron utility is a time-based job scheduler for Unix-like operating systems.
Xbash can create a cronjob for persistence if it determines it is on a Linux system.
Skidmap has installed itself via crontab.
Lsadump also includes NetSync, which performs DCSync over a legacy replication protocol.
Downdelph uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.

InvisiMole can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.
Chaes has used search order hijacking to load a malicious DLL.
RTM has used search order hijacking to force TeamViewer to load a malicious DLL.
Whitefly has used search order hijacking to run the loader Vcrodat.
BackdoorDiplomacy has executed DLL search order hijacking.
Side-loading takes advantage of the DLL search order used by the loader by positioning both the victim application and malicious payload alongside each other.
FinFisher uses DLL side-loading to load malicious programs.
PlugX has used DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus.
Ecipekac can abuse the legitimate application policytool.exe to load a malicious DLL.
Nebulae can use DLL side-loading to gain execution.
Kerrdown can use DLL side-loading to load malicious DLLs.
APT3 has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.
The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable .
Naikon has used DLL side-loading to load malicious DLL's into legitimate executables.
DNS traffic may also be allowed even before network authentication is completed.
TEXTMATE uses DNS TXT records for C2.
POWERSOURCE uses DNS TXT records for C2.
NanHaiShu uses DNS for the C2 communications.
Matryoshka uses DNS for C2.
HTTPBrowser has used DNS for command and control.
PlugX can be configured to use DNS for command and control.
Variants of Anchor can use DNS tunneling to communicate with C2.
SUNBURST used DNS for C2 traffic designed to mimic normal SolarWinds API communications.
ShadowPad has used DNS tunneling for C2 communications.
SombRAT can communicate over DNS with the C2 server.
FIN7 has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.

Adversaries may perform calculations on addresses returned in DNS results to determine which port and IP address to use for command and control, rather than relying on a predetermined port number or the actual returned IP address.
One implementation of DNS Calculation is to take the first three octets of an IP address in a DNS response and use those values to calculate the port for command and control traffic.
Adversaries may set up their own Domain Name System  servers that can be used during targeting.

With control over a DNS server, adversaries can configure DNS applications to provide conditional responses to malware and, generally, have more flexibility in the structure of the DNS-based C2 channel.
Such control can allow for redirection of an organization's traffic, facilitating Collection and Credential Access efforts for the adversary.
Adversaries may attempt to overwrite files and directories with randomly generated data to make it irrecoverable.
BlackEnergy 2 contains a "Destroy" plug-in that destroys data stored on victim hard drives by overwriting file contents.
Olympic Destroyer overwrites files locally and on remote shares.
REvil has the capability to destroy files and folders.
Lazarus Group has used a custom secure delete function to overwrite file contents with data from heap memory.
Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect.
Command and control  information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system.
Adversaries may encrypt data on target systems or on large numbers of systems in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.
They can attempt to render stored data inaccessible by encrypting files or data on local and remote drives and withholding access to a decryption key.
SynAck encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.
Egregor can encrypt all non-system files using a hybrid AES-RSA algorithm prior to displaying a ransom note.
It has used a different AES-256 encryption key per file with a bundled RAS-4096 public encryption key that is unique for each victim.
MegaCortex has used the open-source library, Mbed Crypto, and generated AES keys to carry out the file encryption process.

Only files with sizes 
less than 500MB are encrypted.

Indrik Spider has encrypted domain-controlled systems using BitPaymer.
FIN7 has encrypted virtual disk volumes on ESXi servers using a version of Darkside ransomware.
Adversaries may insert, delete, or manipulate data in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity.
SLOTHFULMEDIA has hashed a string containing system information prior to exfiltration via POST requests.
SideTwist can embed C2 responses in the source code of a fake Flickr webpage.
Operation Wocao has encrypted IP addresses used for "Agent" proxy hops with RC4.
Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Archive Collected Data.
Helminth splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.
RDAT can upload a file via HTTP POST response to the C2 split into 102,400-byte portions.
ObliqueRAT can break large files of interest into smaller chunks to prepare them for exfiltration.

Data from these solutions can be retrieved directly using the cloud provider's APIs.

Adversaries may also abuse external sharing features to share sensitive documents with recipients outside of the organization.

yty collects files with the following extensions: .ppt, .pptx, .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .docm, .rtf, .inp, .xlsm, .csv, .odt, .pps, .vcf and sends them back to the C2 server.
FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files  on the local system.

ROKRAT can request to upload collected host data and additional files.
FrameworkPOS can collect elements related to credit card data from process memory.

Bazar can retrieve information from the infected machine.
Webshell has the ability to copy files on a compromised host.
Nebulae has the capability to upload collected files to C2.
MarkiRAT can upload data from the victim's machine to the C2 server.
SombRAT has collected data and files from a compromised host.
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can steal system information.
Dragonfly 2.0 collected data from local victim systems.
Dust Storm has used Android backdoors capable of exfiltrating specific files directly from the infected devices.

Sandworm Team has exfiltrated internal documents, files, and other data from compromised hosts.
Windigo has used a script to gather credentials in files left on disk by OpenSSH backdoors.
FIN7 has collected files and other sensitive information from a compromised network.
Interactive command shells may be in use, and common functionality within cmd may be used to gather information.
Gamaredon Group malware has collected Microsoft Office documents from mapped network drives.
Fox Kitten has searched network shares to access sensitive documents.
GravityRAT steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.
The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by SPACESHIP.
Remsec has a package that collects documents from any inserted USB sticks.

BADNEWS copies files with certain extensions from USB devices to
a predefined directory.
TajMahal has the ability to steal written CD images and files of interest from previously connected removable drives when they become available again.
Some MiniDuke components use Twitter to initially obtain the address of a C2 server or as a backup if no hard-coded C2 server responds.
BLACKCOFFEE uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server.

Astaroth can store C2 information on cloud hosting services such as AWS and CloudFlare and websites like YouTube and Facebook.
Javali can read C2 information from Google Documents and YouTube.

Default accounts also include default factory/provider set accounts on other types of systems, software, or devices, including the root user account in AWS and the default service account in Kubernetes.
Appliances that come preset with a username and password combination pose a serious threat to organizations that do not change it post installation, as they are easy targets for an adversary.
HyperStack can use default credentials to connect to IPC$ shares on remote machines.
Deleting an instance or virtual machine can remove valuable forensic artifacts and other evidence of suspicious behavior if the instance is not recoverable.
An adversary may also Create Cloud Instance and later terminate the instance after achieving their objectives.
One such example is use of certutil to decode a remote access tool portable executable file that has been hidden inside a certificate file.
Final1stspy uses Python code to deobfuscate base64-encoded strings.
QUADAGENT uses AES and a preshared key to decrypt the custom Base64 routine used to encode strings and scripts.
RGDoor decodes Base64 strings and decrypts strings using a custom XOR algorithm.
FinFisher extracts and decrypts stage 3 malware, which is stored in encrypted resources.
BBSRAT uses Expand to decompress a CAB file into executable content.
RogueRobin decodes an embedded executable using base64 and decompresses it.
CoinTicker decodes the initially-downloaded hidden encoded file using OpenSSL.
BOOSTWRITE has used a a 32-byte long multi-XOR key to decode data inside its payload.
Additionally, Rising Sun can decrypt its configuration data at runtime.
ShimRat has decompressed its core DLL using shellcode once an impersonated antivirus component was running on a system.
Agent Tesla has the ability to decrypt strings encrypted with the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm.
Aria-body has the ability to decrypt the loader configuration and payload DLL.
Ramsay can extract its agent from the body of a malicious document.
BackConfig has used a custom routine to decrypt strings.
Upon execution, Metamorfo has unzipped itself after being downloaded to the system and has performed string decryption.
ComRAT has also used a unique password to decrypt the file used for its hidden file system.
Bundlore has used openssl to decrypt AES encrypted payload data.
Bundlore has also used base64 and RC4 with a hardcoded key to deobfuscate data.
gh0st RAT has decrypted and loaded the gh0st RAT DLL into memory, once the initial dropper executable is launched.
Drovorub has de-obsfuscated XOR encrypted payloads in WebSocket messages.
OnionDuke can use a custom decryption algorithm to decrypt strings.
RegDuke can decrypt strings with a key either stored in the Registry or hardcoded in the code.
Bazar also resolves strings and API calls at runtime.
Raindrop decrypted its Cobalt Strike payload using an AES-256 encryption algorithm in CBC mode with a unique key per sample.
Ebury has verified C2 domain ownership by decrypting the TXT record using an embedded RSA public key.
Sibot can decrypt data received from a C2 and save to a file.
ShadowPad has decrypted a binary blob to start execution.
FYAnti has the ability to decrypt an embedded .NET module.
QakBot can deobfuscate and re-assemble code strings for execution.
BADFLICK can decode shellcode using a custom rotating XOR cipher.
Bandook has decoded its PowerShell script.
Tropic Trooper also decrypted image files which contained a payload.

Direct Network Flood are when one or more systems are used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network.

Additionally, adversaries may use auditpol and its sub-commands in a command prompt to disable auditing or clear the audit policy.
To enable or disable a specified setting or audit category, adversaries may use the /success or /failure parameters.
For example, auditpol /set /category:”Account Logon” /success:disable /failure:disable turns off auditing for the Account Logon category.
Sandworm Team has disabled event logging on compromised systems.

Adversaries may modify and/or disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their malware/tools and activities.
For example, security products may load their own modules and/or modify those loaded by processes to facilitate data collection.
HDoor kills anti-virus found on the victim.
Gold Dragon terminates anti-malware processes if they’re found running on the system.
Brave Prince terminates antimalware processes.
RunningRAT kills antimalware running process.

The data contained in disk structures may include the initial executable code for loading an operating system or the location of the file system partitions on disk.
Disk Structure Wipe may be performed in isolation, or along with Disk Content Wipe if all sectors of a disk are wiped.

To maximize impact on the target organization, malware designed for destroying disk structures may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging other techniques like Valid Accounts, OS Credential Dumping, and SMB/Windows Admin Shares.
Shamoon has been seen overwriting features of disk structure such as the MBR.
APT37 has access to destructive malware that is capable of overwriting a machine's Master Boot Record .

Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of domain accounts.
This information can help adversaries determine which domain accounts exist to aid in follow-on behavior.
Commands such as net user /domain and net group /domain of the Net utility, dscacheutil -q groupon macOS, and ldapsearch on Linux can list domain users and groups.
OSInfo enumerates local and domain users Bankshot gathers domain and account names/information through process monitoring.

Domain accounts can cover users, administrators, and services.

Wizard Spider has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.
Adversaries may patch the authentication process on a domain controller to bypass the typical authentication mechanisms and enable access to accounts.
Skeleton key works through a patch on an enterprise domain controller authentication process  with credentials that adversaries may use to bypass the standard authentication system.
Authenticated access may enable unfettered access to hosts and/or resources within single-factor authentication environments.

Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings.

DLL injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.
DLL injection is commonly performed by writing the path to a DLL in the virtual address space of the target process before loading the DLL by invoking a new thread.
The write can be performed with native Windows API calls such as VirtualAllocEx and WriteProcessMemory, then invoked with CreateRemoteThread .
BlackEnergy injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.
Dyre injects into other processes to load modules.
This “downloaded” file is actually not dropped onto the system.
Kazuar can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.
Elise injects DLL files into iexplore.exe.
Emissary injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.
ZxShell is injected into a shared SVCHOST process.
ShadowPad has injected a DLL into svchost.exe.
SombRAT can execute loadfromfile, loadfromstorage, and loadfrommem to inject a DLL  from disk, storage, or memory respectively.

BackdoorDiplomacy has dropped legitimate software onto a compromised host and used it to execute malicious DLLs.

An Endpoint DoS denies the availability of a service without saturating the network used to provide access to the service.
Attacking each layer requires different techniques that take advantage of bottlenecks that are unique to the respective components.

In some of the worst cases for DDoS, so many systems are used to generate requests that each one only needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to exhaust the target's resources.

In cases where traffic manipulation is used, there may be points in the the global network  where packets can be altered and cause legitimate clients to execute code that directs network packets toward a target in high volume.
Environmental keying uses cryptography to constrain execution or actions based on adversary supplied environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on the target.
Target-specific values can be derived from specific network shares, physical devices, software/software versions, files, joined AD domains, system time, and local/external IP addresses.
By utilizing target-specific values to decrypt the payload the adversary can avoid packaging the decryption key with the payload or sending it over a potentially monitored network connection.

Examples include creating a container configured to mount the host’s filesystem using the bind parameter, which allows the adversary to drop payloads and execute control utilities such as cron on the host, or utilizing a privileged container to run commands on the underlying host.
Adversaries may also escape via Exploitation for Privilege Escalation, such as exploiting vulnerabilities in global symbolic links in order to access the root directory of a host machine.
These personas may be fictitious or impersonate real people.
The persona may exist on a single site or across multiple sites .
Various operating systems have means to monitor and subscribe to events such as logons or other user activity such as running specific applications/binaries.
Adversaries may abuse these mechanisms as a means of maintaining persistent access to a victim via repeatedly executing malicious code.

Since the execution can be proxied by an account with higher permissions, such as SYSTEM or service accounts, an adversary may be able to abuse these triggered execution mechanisms to escalate their privileges.
This may be used in persistent threat incidents as well as BEC  incidents where an adversary can assign more access rights to the accounts they wish to compromise.
This may further enable use of additional techniques for gaining access to systems.

Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an asymmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel.
Asymmetric encryption algorithms are those that use different keys on each end of the channel.
Adversaries may opt to use these encrypted mechanisms that are baked into a protocol.
UNC2452 exfiltrated collected data over a simple HTTPS request to a password-protected archive staged on a victim's OWA servers.
MobileOrder exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.
HOPLIGHT has used its C2 channel to exfiltrate data.
HAWKBALL has sent system information and files over the C2 channel.
Data exfiltration is done by Okrum using the already opened channel with the C2 server.
Lokibot has the ability to initiate contact with command and control  to exfiltrate stolen data.
RDAT can exfiltrate data gathered from the infected system via the established Exchange Web Services API C2 channel.
Drovorub can exfiltrate files over C2 infrastructure.
Stuxnet sends compromised victim information via HTTP.
Spark has exfiltrated data over the C2 channel.
EVILNUM can upload files over the C2 channel from the infected host.
Ebury can exfiltrate SSH credentials through custom DNS queries.
GoldMax can exfiltrate files over the existing C2 channel.
BoxCaon uploads files and data from a compromised host over the existing C2 channel.
Another Lazarus Group malware sample also performs exfiltration over the C2 channel.
Wizard Spider has exfiltrated domain credentials and network enumeration information over command and control  channels.
MuddyWater has used C2 infrastructure to receive exfiltrated data.
APT39 has exfiltrated stolen victim data through C2 communications.
ZIRCONIUM has exfiltrated files via the Dropbox API C2.
Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over a different network medium than the command and control channel.

Adversaries may choose to do this if they have sufficient access or proximity, and the connection might not be secured or defended as well as the primary Internet-connected channel because it is not routed through the same enterprise network
Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a symmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel.
Cherry Picker exfiltrates files over FTP.
Thrip has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.
Web service providers also commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
Ngrok has been used by threat actors to configure servers for data exfiltration.
SPACESHIP copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.
This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.
Machete has a feature to copy files from every drive onto a removable drive in a hidden folder.
Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel.
Examples of cloud storage services include Dropbox and Google Docs.
Exfiltration to these cloud storage services can provide a significant amount of cover to the adversary if hosts within the network are already communicating with the service.
FIN7 has exfiltrated stolen data to the MEGA file sharing site.
If an application is hosted on cloud-based infrastructure and/or is containerized, then exploiting it may lead to compromise of the underlying instance or container.
Siloscape is executed after the attacker gains initial access to a Windows container using a known vulnerability.
GALLIUM exploited a publicly-facing servers including Wildfly/JBoss servers to gain access to the network.
BlackTech has exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability in Microsoft Internet Information Services  6.0, CVE-2017-7269, in order to establish a new HTTP or command and control  server.
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities for initial compromise.
Fox Kitten has exploited known vulnerabilities in Fortinet, PulseSecure, and Palo Alto VPN appliances.
These often do not require an action by the user for the exploit to be executed.
Malicious files will be transmitted directly as attachments or through links to download them.
These require the user to open the document or file for the exploit to run.

### Common Third-party Applications
Other applications that are commonly seen or are part of the software deployed in a target network may also be used for exploitation.
Bankshot leverages a known zero-day vulnerability in Adobe Flash to execute the implant into the victims’ machines.
Cobalt Strike can exploit Oracle Java vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2011-3544, CVE-2013-2465, CVE-2012-4681, and CVE-2013-2460.
They have also used zero-day exploits.
TA459 has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.
Cobalt Group had exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft’s Equation Editor , an Internet Explorer vulnerability , CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2017-8759.
Tropic Trooper has executed commands through Microsoft security vulnerabilities, including CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0802, and CVE-2012-0158.
APT41 leveraged the follow exploits in their operations: CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2019-3396.
Sidewinder has exploited vulnerabilities to gain execution including CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2020-0674.
Credentialing and authentication mechanisms may be targeted for exploitation by adversaries as a means to gain access to useful credentials or circumvent the process to gain access to systems.
Vulnerabilities may exist in defensive security software that can be used to disable or circumvent them.
When initially gaining access to a system, an adversary may be operating within a lower privileged process which will prevent them from accessing certain resources on the system.
ProLock can use CVE-2019-0859 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.
PLATINUM has leveraged a zero-day vulnerability to escalate privileges.
APT32 has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.
The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.
Threat Group-3390 has used CVE-2014-6324 to escalate privileges.
APT33 has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.
Servers are likely a high value target for lateral movement exploitation, but endpoint systems may also be at risk if they provide an advantage or access to additional resources.
Lucifer can exploit multiple vulnerabilities including EternalBlue  and EternalRomance .
Stuxnet propagates using the MS10-061 Print Spooler and MS08-067 Windows Server Service vulnerabilities.
APT28 exploited a Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability to conduct lateral movement.
Wizard Spider has exploited or attempted to exploit Zerologon  and EternalBlue  vulnerabilities.
Adversaries may develop exploits that can be used during targeting.
Rather than finding/modifying exploits from online or purchasing them from exploit vendors, an adversary may develop their own exploits.
As part of the exploit development process, adversaries may uncover exploitable vulnerabilities through methods such as fuzzing and patch analysis.
As with legitimate development efforts, different skill sets may be required for developing exploits.
Rather than developing their own exploits, an adversary may find/modify exploits from online or purchase them from exploit vendors.
In addition to downloading free exploits from the internet, adversaries may purchase exploits from third-party entities.
Third-party entities can include technology companies that specialize in exploit development, criminal marketplaces , or from individuals.

CORALDECK searches for specified files.
Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives.
Remsec is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim.
Octopus can collect information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.
It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.
Zebrocy searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar.
It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry.
NETEAGLE allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system.
It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.
4H RAT has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.
Ixeshe can list file and directory information.
PoetRAT has the ability to list files upon receiving the ls command from C2.
Okrum has used DriveLetterView to enumerate drive information.
down_new has the ability to list the directories on a compromised host.
BackConfig has the ability to identify folders and files related to previous infections.
REvil has the ability to identify specific files and directories that are not to be encrypted.
DropBook can collect the names of all files and folders in the Program Files directories.
Caterpillar WebShell can search for files in directories.
Conti can discover files on a local system.
Bisonal can retrieve a file list of a specified folder.
Cuba can enumerate files by using a variety of functions.
RainyDay can use a file exfiltration tool to collect recently changed files with specific extensions.
Babuk has the ability to enumerate files on a targeted system.
BLUELIGHT can enumerate files and collect associated metadata.
GrimAgent has the ability to enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.
The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.
Sowbug identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx.
Dark Caracal collected file listings of all default Windows directories.
MuddyWater has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."
Gamaredon Group macros can scan for Microsoft Word and Excel files to inject with additional malicious macros.
Gamaredon Group has also used its backdoors to automatically list interesting files  found on a system.
Fox Kitten has used WizTree to obtain network files and directory listings.
Mustang Panda has searched the entire target system for DOC, DOCX, PPT, PPTX, XLS, XLSX, and PDF files.

Specific file and directory modifications may be a required step for many techniques, such as establishing Persistence via Accessibility Features, Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts, Unix Shell Configuration Modification, or tainting/hijacking other instrumental binary/configuration files via Hijack Execution Flow.
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host firmware that can be used during targeting.
Information about host firmware may include a variety of details such as type and versions on specific hosts, which may be used to infer more information about hosts in the environment .
Bad Rabbit has used an executable that installs a modified bootloader to prevent normal boot-up.
Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning  is also typically used by Windows systems as a backup protocol when SMB is blocked or fails.
WebDAV is an extension of HTTP and will typically operate over TCP ports 80 and 443.
The document can include, for example, a request similar to file://remote address/Normal.dotm to trigger the SMB request.

Dragonfly 2.0 has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.
The generation of web credentials often requires secret values, such as passwords, Private Keys, or other cryptographic seed values.
Once forged, adversaries may use these web credentials to access resources , which may bypass multi-factor and other authentication protection mechanisms.
Adversaries may mimic common operating system GUI components to prompt users for credentials with a seemingly legitimate prompt.
iKitten prompts the user for their credentials.
Adversaries may modify file attributes that signify programs are from untrusted sources to subvert Gatekeeper controls in macOS.
When documents, applications, or programs are downloaded an extended attribute  called com.apple.quarantine can be set on the file by the application performing the download.
Gatekeeper also monitors an application's usage of dynamic libraries  loaded outside the application folder on any quarantined binary, often using the dlopen function.
The quarantine flag is an opt-in system and not imposed by macOS.
If an application opts-in, a file downloaded from the Internet will be given a quarantine flag before being saved to disk.
Information about hosts may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets  or Search Victim-Owned Websites.
Information about victims may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets  or Search Victim-Owned Websites.
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's networks that can be used during targeting.
Information about networks may include a variety of details, including administrative data  as well as specifics regarding its topology and operations.
Golden tickets require adversaries to interact with the Key Distribution Center  in order to obtain TGS.
The KRBTGT password hash may be obtained using OS Credential Dumping and privileged access to a domain controller.
Group Policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory .
Adversaries may modify Group Policy Objects  to subvert the intended discretionary access controls for a domain, usually with the intention of escalating privileges on the domain.
Egregor can modify the GPO to evade detection.
Indrik Spider has used Group Policy Objects to deploy batch scripts.

The following tools and scripts can be used to gather and decrypt the password file from Group Policy Preference XML files:
* Metasploit’s post exploitation module: post/windows/gather/credentials/gpp
* Get-GPPPassword
* gpprefdecrypt.py
On the SYSVOL share, adversaries may use the following command to enumerate potential GPP XML files: dir /s * .xml
 APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like Gpppassword to gather credentials.
Adversaries may smuggle data and files past content filters by hiding malicious payloads inside of seemingly benign HTML files.
Adversaries may deliver payloads to victims that bypass security controls through HTML Smuggling by abusing JavaScript Blobs and/or HTML5 download attributes.

Security controls such as web content filters may not identify smuggled malicious files inside of HTML/JS files, as the content may be based on typically benign MIME types such as text/plain and/or text/html.
EnvyScout contains JavaScript code that can extract an encoded blob from its HTML body and write it to disk.
While public references of usage by threat actors are scarce, many red teams/penetration testers leverage hardware additions for initial access.
Hidden file systems, sometimes referred to as virtual file systems, can be implemented in numerous ways.
Another implementation could be for an adversary to drop their own portable partition image as a file on top of the standard file system.
To prevent normal users from accidentally changing special files on a system, most operating systems have the concept of a ‘hidden’ file.
Users must explicitly ask to show the hidden files either via a series of Graphical User Interface  prompts or with command line switches .
Many applications create these hidden files and folders to store information so that it doesn’t clutter up the user’s workspace.
MacSpy stores itself in ~/Library/.DS_Stores/  Calisto uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.
to make it a hidden file.
iKitten saves itself with a leading "."
Micropsia creates a new hidden directory to store all components' outputs in a dedicated sub-folder for each.
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D sets the main loader file’s attributes to hidden.
WannaCry uses attrib +h to make some of its files hidden.
OSX/Shlayer executes a .command script from a hidden directory in a mounted DMG.
Machete has the capability to exfiltrate stolen data to a hidden folder on a removable drive.
Attor can set attributes of log files and directories to HIDDEN, SYSTEM, ARCHIVE, or a combination of those.
Lokibot has the ability to copy itself to a hidden file and directory.
InvisiMole can create hidden system directories.
to plist filenames, unlisting them from the Finder app and default Terminal directory listings.
Tropic Trooper has created a hidden directory under C:\ProgramData\Apple\Updates\ and C:\Users\Public\Documents\Flash\.
Normal users may want to hide users when there are many users accounts on a given system or want to keep an account hidden from the other users on the system.
Dragonfly 2.0 modified the Registry to hide create user accounts.
Similarly, on macOS the configurations for how applications run are listed in property list  files.
Adversaries may abuse these functionalities to hide otherwise visible windows from users so as not to alert the user to adversary activity on the system.
Kivars has the ability to conceal its activity through hiding active windows.
Agent Tesla has used ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden to hide windows.
InvisiMole has executed legitimate tools in hidden windows.
Cuba has executed hidden PowerShell windows.
Adversaries may attempt to hide artifacts associated with their behaviors to evade detection.
How the operating system locates libraries to be used by a program can also be intercepted.
One of Dtrack can replace the normal flow of a program execution with malicious code.
IIS provides several mechanisms to extend the functionality of the web servers.
ISAPI extensions and filters may have access to all IIS web requests and responses.
IIS modules can be written as a DLL that exports RegisterModule, or as a .NET application that interfaces with ASP.NET APIs to access IIS HTTP requests.
Information about assigned IP addresses may include a variety of details, such as which IP addresses are in use.
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's business tempo that can be used during targeting.
When a process is created, a debugger present in an application’s IFEO will be prepended to the application’s name, effectively launching the new process under the debugger .
In some Linux systems, this is set by default to "ignoreboth" which covers both of the previous examples.
This not only involves impairing preventative defenses, such as firewalls and anti-virus, but also detection capabilities that defenders can use to audit activity and identify malicious behavior.
This may also span both native defenses as well as supplemental capabilities installed by users and administrators.
Unlike Upload Malware, this technique focuses on adversaries implanting an image in a registry within a victim’s environment.
An adversary may attempt to block indicators or events typically captured by sensors from being gathered and analyzed.

ETW interruption can be achieved multiple ways, however most directly by defining conditions using the PowerShell Set-EtwTraceProvider cmdlet or by interfacing directly with the Registry to make alterations.
In the case of network-based reporting of indicators, an adversary may block traffic associated with reporting to prevent central analysis.

This may be accomplished by many means, such as stopping a local process responsible for forwarding telemetry and/or creating a host-based firewall rule to block traffic to specific hosts responsible for aggregating events, such as security information and event management  products.
InvisiMole has undergone regular technical improvements in an attempt to evade detection.
Waterbear can scramble functions not to be executed again with random values.
GALLIUM ensured each payload had a unique hash, including by using different types of packers.
Locations and format of logs are platform or product-specific, however standard operating system logs are captured as Windows events or Linux/macOS files such as Bash History and /var/log/*.
Metamorfo has a command to delete a Registry key it uses, \Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\notes.
EVILNUM has a function called "DeleteLeftovers" to remove certain artifacts of the attack.
BlackEnergy has removed the watermark associated with enabling the TESTSIGNING boot configuration option by removing the relevant strings in the user32.dll.mui of the system.
UNC2452 removed evidence of email export requests using Remove-MailboxExportRequest.
Dragonfly deleted system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs from a victim.
Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking cmd.

Agent Tesla can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.

can download and execute a second-stage payload.

Exaramel for Linux has a command to download a file from  and to a remote C2 server.
Machete can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.
VBShower has the ability to download VBS files to the target computer.

SLOTHFULMEDIA has downloaded files onto a victim machine.

The group's JavaScript backdoor is also capable of downloading files.
Several Lazarus Group malware families are capable of downloading and executing binaries from its C2 server.
The Ritsol backdoor trojan used by Elderwood can download files onto a compromised host from a remote location.
Sharpshooter downloaded additional payloads after a target was infected with a first-stage downloader.
APT39 has downloaded tools to compromised hosts.
Evilnum can deploy additional components or tools as needed.
Darkhotel has used first-stage payloads that download additional malware from C2 servers.
APT34 can download remote files onto victims.
Dragonfly downloaded tools from a remote server after they were inside the victim network.
Maze has attempted to delete the shadow volumes of infected machines, once before and once after the encryption process.
REvil can use vssadmin to delete volume shadow copies and bcdedit to disable recovery features.
InvisiMole can can remove all system restore points.
BitPaymer attempts to remove the backup shadow files from the host using vssadmin.exe Delete Shadows /All /Quiet.
HELLOKITTY can delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.
ProLock can use vssadmin.exe to remove volume shadow copies.
Adversaries may use methods of capturing user input to obtain credentials or collect information.
Kobalos has used a compromised SSH client to capture the hostname, port, username and password used to establish an SSH connection from the compromised host.
captures keystrokes.
APT39 has utilized tools to capture mouse movements.
APT34 has used a keylogging tool called KEYPUNCH.
Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.
Certificates are commonly used for establishing secure TLS/SSL communications within a web browser.

Atypical root certificates have also been pre-installed on systems by the manufacturer or in the software supply chain and were used in conjunction with malware/adware to provide Adversary-in-the-Middle capability for intercepting information transmitted over secure TLS/SSL communications.
Root certificates  can also be cloned and reinstalled.

In macOS, the Ay MaMi malware uses /usr/bin/security add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain /path/to/malicious/cert to install a malicious certificate as a trusted root certificate into the system keychain.
Dok installs a root certificate to aid in Adversary-in-the-Middle actions using the command add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain /tmp/filename.
menuPass has used InstallUtil.exe to execute malicious software.
IPC is typically used by processes to share data, communicate with each other, or synchronize execution.

IPC mechanisms may differ depending on OS, but typically exists in a form accessible through programming languages/libraries or native interfaces such as Windows Dynamic Data Exchange or Component Object Model.
Since internally defacing systems exposes an adversary's presence, it often takes place after other intrusion goals have been accomplished.
Adversaries may use an internal proxy to direct command and control traffic between two or more systems in a compromised environment.
CHOPSTICK used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.
Cobalt Strike can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts.

Internal spearphishing is multi-staged attack where an email account is owned either by controlling the user's device with previously installed malware or by compromising the account credentials of the user.
Gamaredon Group has used an Outlook VBA module on infected systems to send phishing emails with malicious attachments to other employees within the organization.
Adversaries may check for Internet connectivity on compromised systems.
BADNEWS is sometimes signed with an invalid Authenticode certificate in an apparent effort to make it look more legitimate.
JScript is the Microsoft implementation of the same scripting standard.
JScript is interpreted via the Windows Script engine and thus integrated with many components of Windows such as the Component Object Model and Internet Explorer HTML Application  pages.
GRIFFON is written in and executed as JavaScript.
Bundlore can execute JavaScript by injecting it into the victim's browser.
The Cobalt Strike System Profiler can use JavaScript to perform reconnaissance actions.
Chaes has used JavaScript and Node.Js information stealer script that exfiltrates data using the node process.
FIN7 used JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.
Downdelph inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.
Wizard Spider has used Rubeus, MimiKatz Kerberos module, and the Invoke-Kerberoast cmdlet to steal AES hashes.
FIN7 has used Kerberoasting for credential access and to enable lateral movement.
Adversaries may modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot.
Keychain files are located in ~/Library/Keychains/,/Library/Keychains/, and /Network/Library/Keychains/.
To manage their credentials, users have to use additional credentials to access their keychain.
If an adversary knows the credentials for the login keychain, then they can get access to all the other credentials stored in this vault.
By default, the passphrase for the keychain is the user’s logon credentials.
Unlike Credential API Hooking, this focuses solely on API functions intended for processing keystroke data.
* Custom drivers.
* Modify System Image may provide adversaries with hooks into the operating system of network devices to read raw keystrokes for login sessions.
BadPatch has a keylogging capability.
When it first starts, BADNEWS spawns a new thread to log keystrokes.
RunningRAT captures keystrokes and sends them back to the C2 server.
OwaAuth captures and DES-encrypts credentials before writing the username and password to a log file, C:\log.txt.
Catchamas collects keystrokes from the victim’s machine.
Bandook contains keylogging capabilities.
Daserf can log keystrokes.
FakeM contains a keylogger module.
Kasidet has the ability to initiate keylogging.
Remexi gathers and exfiltrates keystrokes from the machine.
Fysbis can perform keylogging.
Cadelspy has the ability to log keystrokes on the compromised host.
Metamorfo has a command to launch a keylogger and capture keystrokes on the victim’s machine.
Peppy can log keystrokes on compromised hosts.
APT39 has used tools for capturing keystrokes.
Ajax Security Team has used CWoolger and MPK, custom-developed malware, which recorded all keystrokes on an infected system.
The LC_LOAD_DYLIB header in a Mach-O binary tells macOS and OS X which dynamic libraries  to load during execution time.

Although any changes will invalidate digital signatures on binaries because the binary is being modified, this can be remediated by simply removing the LC_CODE_SIGNATURE command from the binary so that the signature isn’t checked at load time.
By responding to LLMNR/NBT-NS network traffic, adversaries may spoof an authoritative source for name resolution to force communication with an adversary controlled system.
Wizard Spider has used the Invoke-Inveigh PowerShell cmdlets, likely for name service poisoning.

Adversaries with SYSTEM access to a host may attempt to access Local Security Authority  secrets, which can contain a variety of different credential materials, such as credentials for service accounts.
LSA secrets are stored in the registry at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SECURITY\Policy\Secrets.
LSA secrets can also be dumped from memory.
Mimikatz can be used to extract secrets from memory.
* CredSSP:  Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.
Olympic Destroyer contains a module that tries to obtain credentials from LSASS, similar to Mimikatz.
MuddyWater has performed credential dumping with Mimikatz and procdump64.exe.
Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using Mimikatz.
FIN8 harvests credentials using Invoke-Mimikatz or Windows Credentials Editor .
They have also dumped the LSASS process memory using the MiniDump function.
APT39 has used Mimikatz, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne, Mimikatz, and ProcDump to dump credentials.
GALLIUM used a modified version of Mimikatz along with a PowerShell-based Mimikatz to dump credentials on the victim machines.
Kimsuky has gathered credentials using Mimikatz and ProcDump.

Chimera has copied tools between compromised hosts using SMB.
Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence.
Property list files use the Label, ProgramArguments , and RunAtLoad keys to identify the Launch Agent's name, executable location, and execution time.
The Launch Agent name may be disguised by using a name from the related operating system or benign software.
Calisto adds a .plist file to the /Library/LaunchAgents folder to maintain persistence.
Proton persists via Launch Agent.
Bundlore can persist via a LaunchAgent.
CookieMiner has installed multiple new Launch Agents in order to maintain persistence for cryptocurrency mining software.
Launch Daemons require elevated privileges to install, are executed for every user on a system prior to login, and run in the background without the need for user interaction.

During the macOS initialization startup, the launchd process loads the parameters for launch-on-demand system-level daemons from plist files found in /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/ and /Library/LaunchDaemons/.
The daemon name may be disguised by using a name from a related operating system or benign software  Masquerading.
When the Launch Daemon is executed, the program inherits administrative permissions.
XCSSET uses the ssh launchdaemon to elevate privileges, bypass system controls, and enable remote access to the victim.
Calisto uses launchctl to enable screen sharing on the victim’s machine.
It also uses launchctl to unload all Launch Daemons when updating to a newer version of LoudMiner.

Adversaries may clone legitimate sites to serve as the link target, this can include cloning of login pages of legitimate web services or organization login pages in an effort to harvest credentials during Spearphishing Link.
Adversaries may purchase domains similar to legitimate domains  during acquisition of infrastructure  to help facilitate Malicious Link.
Silent Librarian has cloned victim organization login pages and staged them for later use in credential harvesting campaigns.
OSX/Shlayer can use the chmod utility to set a file as executable, such as chmod 777 or chmod +x.
Penquin can add the executable flag to a downloaded file.
Kinsing has used chmod to modify permissions on key files for use.
XCSSET uses the chmod +x command to grant executable permissions to the malicious file.

FIN10 has moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.
PROMETHIUM has created admin accounts on a compromised host.
Operation Wocao has used local account credentials found during the intrusion for lateral movement and privilege escalation.
FLASHFLOOD stages data it copies from the local system or removable drives in the "%WINDIR%\$NtUninstallKB885884$\" directory.
Calisto uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.
NOKKI can collect data from the victim and stage it in LOCALAPPDATA%\MicroSoft Updatea\uplog.tmp.
Carbon creates a base directory that contains the files and folders that are collected.
InvisiMole determines a working directory where it stores all the gathered data about the compromised machine.
Exaramel for Windows specifies a path to store files scheduled for exfiltration.
Ramsay can stage data prior to exfiltration in %APPDATA%\Microsoft\UserSetting and %APPDATA%\Microsoft\UserSetting\MediaCache.
Dyre has the ability to create files in a TEMP folder to act as a database to store information.
ECCENTRICBANDWAGON has stored keystrokes and screenshots within the %temp%\GoogleChrome, %temp%\Downloads, and %temp%\TrendMicroUpdate directories.
ObliqueRAT can copy specific files, webcam captures, and screenshots to local directories.
menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.
Kimsuky has staged collected data files under C:\Program Files\Common Files\System\Ole DB\.
Mustang Panda has stored collected credential files in c:\windows\temp prior to exfiltration.
Mustang Panda has also stored documents for exfiltration in a hidden folder on USB drives.
Indrik Spider has stored collected date in a .tmp file.
Outlook stores data locally in offline data files with an extension of .ost.

Smoke Loader searches through Outlook files and directories .
Crimson contains a command to collect and exfiltrate emails from Outlook.

admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to list local groups: net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download OilRig has used net localgroup administrators to find local administrators on compromised systems.
Login items installed using the Service Management Framework leverage launchd, are not visible in the System Preferences, and can only be removed by the application that created them.
NETWIRE can persist via startup options for Login items.
macOS allows logon scripts  to be executed whenever a specific user logs into a system.
Access to login hook scripts may allow an adversary to insert additional malicious code.
This is done via adding a path to a script to the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key.
Zebrocy performs persistence with a logon script via adding to the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript.
Adversaries may abuse mmc.exe to proxy execution of malicious .msc files.
Microsoft Management Console, or MMC, is a signed Windows binary and is used in several ways in either its GUI or in a command prompt.
Another common example is mmc gpedit.msc, which will open the Group Policy Editor application window.
Adversaries may use MSBuild to proxy execution of code through a trusted Windows utility.
Frankenstein has used MSbuild to execute an actor-created file.
Protocols such as SMTP/S, POP3/S, and IMAP that carry electronic mail may be very common in environments.

OLDBAIT can use SMTP for C2.
Zebrocy uses SMTP and POP3 for C2.

Turla has used multiple backdoors which communicate with a C2 server via email attachments.

While Malicious File frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it.
